History of Mukilteo Mayors | Mukilteo, WA

![](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=637)


1. [Mayor’s Office](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/179/Mayors-Office)

Mukilteo, Washington was incorporated on May 8, 1947 with a population of 775 residents and elected School Administrator Alfred Tunem as its first Mayor. At that time, Mukilteo encompassed 794 acres. Since 1947, there have been 13 Mayors, 12 men and one woman, serving the City and residents; some for only a short time, others for 4 year-year terms. In 1991, during Mayor Sullivan's tenure, the City annexed Harbour Pointe and the population grew from about 6,900 to almost 13,000, while the area of the City grew to 6.6 square miles. In 2019, Mukilteo's population was 21,350.

[Mayor Chronology 1947 to Present (PDF)](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/DocumentCenter/View/290)

Joe Marine
----------

**Mayor 2022 to present**

Mayor Marine served on the Mukilteo City Council from 1998 to 2001 before accepting a position to serve as a state legislator. in 2005, Mayor Marine was elected Mayor and served two terms. Mr. Marine was again elected to the Mukilteo City Council in 2019, and then elected as Mayor in 2021. He began serving his new term on January 1, 2022.

Phone Number: 425-263-8018
[Email Joe Marine](mailto:jmarine@mukilteowa.gov)

![Joe Marine](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=305 "Joe Marine")

Jennifer Gregerson
------------------

**Mayor 2014 to 2021**

Jennifer Gregerson, the City's first woman mayor, was elected in 2013 and re-elected to a second term in 2017. Prior to her election as Mayor, she served on the Mukilteo City Council from 2004 - 2013. Mayor Gregerson annually announces an Action Agenda that focuses on housing, public safety, safe neighborhoods and a sustainable, well-run city.

![Jennifer Gregerson](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=304 "Jennifer Gregerson")

Joe Marine
----------

**Mayor 2006 to 2013**

Mayor Marine served on the Mukilteo City Council from 1998 to 2001 before accepting a position to serve as a state legislator. in 2005, Mayor Marine was elected Mayor and served two-terms. Mr. Marine was again elected to the Mukilteo City Council in 2019. During Mayor Marine's tenure, the City was named 10th out of the top 100 U.S. small towns to live in by Money Magazine (2009). In late 2013, The City acquired Japanese Gulch.

![Joe Marine](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=303 "Joe Marine")

Don Doran
---------

**Mayor 1998 to 2005**

Mayor Doran served two terms as Mayor of Mukilteo. During Mayor Doran's tenure, the City acquired Mukilteo State Park from the state and renamed it "Mukilteo Lighthouse Park" in 2003.

![Don Doran](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=302 "Don Doran")

Brian Sullivan
--------------

**Mayor 1990 to 1997**

Mayor Sullivan served on the Mukilteo City Council from 1986 to 1989 then served two terms as Mayor. In 2007, Mayor Sullivan was elected to and served three terms on the Snohomish County Council. In 2019, he was elected County Treasurer.


![Brian Sullivan](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=301 "Brian Sullivan")

Emory Cole
----------

**Mayor 1986 to 1989**

Mayor Cole served one term from 1986 to 1989. He is the owner of Emory's on Silver Lake restaurant.


![Emory Cole](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=300 "Emory Cole")

John Corbett
------------

**1982 to 1985**

Mayor Corbett served one term from 1982 to 1985. Mr. Corbett owned several businesses in the area and was a real estate developer. Mayor Corbett passed away in 2007.

![John Corbett](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=299 "John Corbett")

John Sweat
----------

**Mayor 1977 to 1981**

Mayor Sweat was appointed Mayor Pro Tem by the City Council on November 7, 1977. He was elected Mayor in 1978 and served until the end of 1981. Prior to serving as Mayor, he served in the Navy and worked as an engineer. During Mayor Sweat's tenure, development of Harbour Pointe began in 1978. Mayor Sweat passed away in 2012.

![John Sweat](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=298 "John Sweat")

James Huetson
-------------

**Mayor 1974 to 1977**

Mayor Huetson served from January 21, 1974 until his resignation on October 17, 1977. He also served on several special committee positions within Snohomish County. After he retired from GTE in 1988, he worked as a special deputy with the Sheriff's office from 1989 to 1996. Mayor Heutson passed away in 2017.

![James Huetson](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=297 "James Huetson")

Jerimiah Lavell
---------------

**Mayor 1972 to 1973**

Jerimiah "Jerry" Lavell was appointed by the City Council on January 17, 1972 and served through 1973. Mayor Lavell passed away in 1989.


![Jerimiah Lavell](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=296 "Jerimiah Lavell")

J.O. Simpson
------------

**Mayor 1970 to 1971**

Mayor Simpson was elected Mayor on November 17, 1969, and resigned in November 1971. That same month, Neptune's Galley opened on Front Street, the current home of Diamond Knot. Mayor Simpson passed away in 2008.

![JO Simpson](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=295 "JO Simpson")

Ronald Kane
-----------

**Mayor 1964 to 1969**

Mayor Kane was elected Mayor on April 6, 1964 served one term from 1964 to 1969. In 1967, the Boeing Everett plant opened and in 1969, the Boeing freeway was built. Mr. Kane was a 25-year volunteer of the Mukilteo Fire Department, and served 8 years on the City Council before becoming Mayor. Mayor Kane passed away in 2002.

![Ronald Kane](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=294 "Ronald Kane")

Richard Taylor
--------------

**Mayor 1956 to 1964**

Mayor Taylor was elected to the first City Council in 1947 and served until 1951. He was elected Mayor on June 4, 1956, and served two terms from 1956 to 1964. After serving as Mayor, Mr. Taylor went on to the state legislature, where he spent three terms. Mayor Taylor worked to secure the land for Mukilteo State Park, now known as Lighthouse Park. He may be best known for co-owning with his brother Ed Taylor the restaurant "Taylor's Landing", which is now Ivar's. Mayor Taylor passed away in 2005.

![Richard Taylor](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=293 "Richard Taylor")

Alfred Tunem
------------

**Mayor 1947 to 1956**

Mayor Tunem was the first Mayor of Mukilteo, serving from 1947 to 1956. He was born in Norway, and passed away in 1972.


![Alfred Tunem](https://www.mukilteowa.gov/ImageRepository/Document?documentID=292 "Alfred Tunem")
